content: W hat makes humans human? Is it our relentless curiosity? Our use of language? The collaborative and complex nature of our societies and communities? Economists are likely to point to something else: our propensity for engaging in sophisticated systems of trade. “Nobody ever saw a dog make a fair and deliberate exchange of one bone for another with another dog,” the proto-economist Adam Smith once wrote . “Nobody ever saw one animal, by its gestures and natural cries, signify to another, this is mine, that, yours; I am willing to give this for that.” Economists sometimes refer to humans as homo economicus because of our ability to trade, to create markets, to respond rationally to supply and demand. But what if Adam Smith was wrong? What if, far from being the only rational economic actors, humans are actually less rational than some animals? In this week’s episode of Freakonomics Radio , we explore monkey business, fish tales, and ask the following question: if homo is not the only economicus , what does that make us? K eith Chen, a behavioral economist and professor at the UCLA business school, has been researching monkeys since he was a graduate student at Harvard. The first monkey experiments Chen worked on, with the primatologist Marc Hauser, explored reciprocity and altruism. The researchers put two tamarin monkeys in separate cages where they could see each other; they equipped Monkey A with a lever that dropped a marshmallow into Monkey B’s cage. Later, Chen and Hauser then checked to see if Monkey B was nice to Monkey A. “Niceness” was measured by whether Monkey B would reciprocate by pulling its lever to give Monkey A a marshmallow. Often, they did: about 40% of the time. This compared to just 7% of the time for a monkey who hadn’t given his partner a marshmallow. The takeaway, for tamarins, was this: you do something nice for me, I’ll do something nice for you. You do nothing for me? I’ll pass. In a second variation of the experiment, Monkey A pulled a lever that delivered a marshmallow to both himself and Monkey B. What happens when Monkey B sees his marshmallow as a mere byproduct of Monkey A’s self-interest? In this case, Monkey B reciprocates only 3% of the time. That’s even less than if Monkey A hadn’t given him a marshmallow at all. “A true altruist versus an accidental altruist,” says Chen. “Monkeys are smart enough to distinguish.” This distinction was surprising because it looks an awful lot like what humans do while making economic decisions. Chen wondered if monkeys resemble humans in their economic decision-making in other ways as well. He taught the monkeys to use metal washers as a form of money and then tested how well they conformed to one of the cardinal laws of economics: the law of demand. Economists often use a test called the Generalized Axiom of Revealed Preferences (GARP) to evaluate humans’ behavior. The test, in Chen’s words, puts parameters on behaviors considered “rational responses to price shocks.” Chen gave the test to the monkeys. “When we test the capuchin monkeys on this basic rational response to price shocks, they pass GARP as well as any human beings that you can test,” Chen says. “In fact, it’s not until about age 10 or 11 that humans even start to pass GARP at this basic level that we observe the capuchin monkeys passing it at.” Chen didn’t stop there. He found that monkeys even exhibit similarly irrational responses to humans with respect to, for example, the endowment effect . “Every month, we would just be flabbergasted again at how sophisticated our monkeys looked,” Chen says. “Specifically, at economic activity. But also, the subtle ways in which they looked irrational and they looked emotional, in exactly the same ways that people do.“ So Chen had found that capuchin monkeys, once they were taught to use money, behaved rationally, like we do, when it comes to price theory; and irrationally, like we do, when it comes to the endowment effect. All of this research, however, had happened in tightly controlled lab experiments. What did animals’ economic activities look like in the wild? Ronald Noë is a primatologist who spent two decades as a professor at the University of Strasbourg, in France . He got his start as a grad student under Frans de Waal, observing chimpanzees at the Arnhem Zoo in the Netherlands. Noë was interested in studying cooperation in primates. By the early 1980s, he was observing baboons, in the wild, in Kenya. In these baboon groups, alpha males had access to females, and kept the lower-ranking males away. But Noë found that lower-ranking males could band together to challenge the alphas. If the low-ranking males were successful in chasing off the high-ranking male, they were entitled to a certain amount of access to the female. But these bargains pose a dilemma. If two low-ranking males worked together to steal a female from an alpha, only one of them could mate with the female at a time. So how could this cooperation work? At the time, there were, in biology circles, two primary theories of cooperation. One was “kin selection,” which involves helping out a closely related individual to make it more likely for your own genes to be passed on. But the baboons Noë was observing weren’t that closely related. The other theory was called “reciprocal altruism” — you scratch my back, I’ll scratch yours. Kind of like the marshmallow monkeys that Chen had studied. According to this theory, the lower-ranking males should alternate who gets access to the female after they’ve chased away the alpha male. If the baboons didn’t alternate, then you would expect the baboon who didn’t have frequent access to the female to reject the compromise, to walk away. Among the low-ranking baboons that Noë was studying, the most powerful one was named Stu. Noë noticed that Stu was getting more mating time than his less-powerful baboon partners. Despite that, the other baboons continued to form coalitions with Stu. Noë realized that reciprocal altruism could not explain the behavior he was seeing. It had to be something else. Stu, it turned out, was utilizing his strength to get the best deals for himself. If a less-powerful baboon wasn’t willing to give Stu more mating time, Stu would simply move on to the next baboon. Stu could choose between partners, effectively bargaining to raise the price of his cooperation. Partner choice — that was Noë’s big idea. And with that insight, Noë realized that what he was observing was an economic transaction. “Partner choice is what drives markets, what drives trade, what drives everything, because you force the others to outbid in competition,” he explains. “And that’s basically what a market is.” When Noë published his research in the early 1990s, he called this situation a “biological market.” The idea didn’t go over so well with biologists, or the big biology journals. Over time, however, Noë’s ideas started to gain traction. One of the biologists who picked up the idea, and extended it beyond primates, was a student of Noë’s, Redouan Bshary . Bshary studies animal behavior and teaches at the University of Neuchatel, in Switzerland. He started out doing fieldwork with Noë but ultimately transitioned to studying coral reefs. One little fish captured Bshary’s attention. It’s called a cleaner wrasse, which is known for eating the parasites and dead scales off other fish. Each cleaner wrasse sets up shop at a particular spot on the reef — kind of like a string of car washes — and the client fish line up at their favorite station to have their parasites removed. These fish have 2,000 cleaning interactions per day, and a single “client fish” typically visits a cleaner fish between 5 and 30 times a day. Bshary began to observe patterns in the interactions of the cleaner fish with their clients. For one thing, there were two different types of client fish. There were the fish with limited range, who had access to just one cleaner wrasse. (Bshary called these fish “residents.”) Then there were the fish with more range, who could choose between many different cleaning stations. (These fish, Bshary called “visitors.”) The cleaner fish, Bshary noticed, know the difference between visitors and residents — they vary their level of service depending on the fish they’re serving. For instance, they might make a resident fish wait while they service a visitor, knowing that a visitor might take his business elsewhere if there’s a line. “And that’s exactly what visitors are doing,” Bshary says. “If the service is good, there’s a higher chance that you go back to the same station for your next inspection. If the service is lousy, you go to a different station for your next inspection.” The cleaner fish even provide some special services, like massages, to certain fish. This was exactly what Bshary had been looking for. The client fish were choosing their partners, and the cleaner fish were dialing their service up or down in response to the amount of choice that each client had. And, as economic theory would predict, the client fish with more choice reaped greater benefits. Bshary has, by now, spent two decades studying the cleaner wrasse. Long enough to convince him — and his fellow animal behaviorists — that these animals plainly engage in what humans would recognize as economic transactions. I t’s not just baboons and cleaner fish. There’s growing evidence that biological markets exist across a very wide range of animals. Researchers have found that paper wasps, and even plants and fungi, engage in biological markets. A fungus-to-plant nutrient exchange is, of course, pretty far from what we humans think of as markets. There is no cognition going on there, or at least what we think of as cognition. Doesn’t trade require an intention to trade? And what about all the emotions that accompany intention? Noë believes that is what makes biological markets more rational than human ones. The more we think, Noë suggests, the more capacity we have for cognitive activity or decision-making, and the more likely we are to be less rational. “I think the less you use cognitive mechanisms, the least brain you have,” says Noë. “If you have no neurons, you have a better chance of being very rational in your behavior than when you use them. When you use your brain, you can make all kinds of mistakes.” You can find the full Freakonomics Radio episode “The Invisible Paw,” at Freakonomics.com . You can also listen on Stitcher , Apple Podcasts , or any other podcast platform. Special thanks to Ben Crair , who contributed to this reporting and whose Bloomberg article “ The Secret Economic Lives of Animals ” first brought this topic to our attention.
html:
Homepage
Homepage
Economy
Become a memberSign inGet started

Freakonomics Radio

The Invisible Paw

Humans, it has long been thought, are the only animal to engage in economic activity. But what if we’ve had it exactly backward?

Stephen J. Dubner/ Freakonomics Radio
Apr 26

What makes humans human? Is it our relentless curiosity? Our use of language? The collaborative and complex nature of our societies and communities?

Economists are likely to point to something else: our propensity for engaging in sophisticated systems of trade. “Nobody ever saw a dog make a fair and deliberate exchange of one bone for another with another dog,” the proto-economist Adam Smith once wrote. “Nobody ever saw one animal, by its gestures and natural cries, signify to another, this is mine, that, yours; I am willing to give this for that.”

Economists sometimes refer to humans as homo economicus because of our ability to trade, to create markets, to respond rationally to supply and demand. But what if Adam Smith was wrong? What if, far from being the only rational economic actors, humans are actually less rational than some animals?

In this week’s episode of Freakonomics Radio, we explore monkey business, fish tales, and ask the following question: if homo is not the only economicus, what does that make us?

Keith Chen, a behavioral economist and professor at the UCLA business school, has been researching monkeys since he was a graduate student at Harvard. The first monkey experiments Chen worked on, with the primatologist Marc Hauser, explored reciprocity and altruism. The researchers put two tamarin monkeys in separate cages where they could see each other; they equipped Monkey A with a lever that dropped a marshmallow into Monkey B’s cage.

Later, Chen and Hauser then checked to see if Monkey B was nice to Monkey A. “Niceness” was measured by whether Monkey B would reciprocate by pulling its lever to give Monkey A a marshmallow. Often, they did: about 40% of the time. This compared to just 7% of the time for a monkey who hadn’t given his partner a marshmallow. The takeaway, for tamarins, was this: you do something nice for me, I’ll do something nice for you. You do nothing for me? I’ll pass.

In a second variation of the experiment, Monkey A pulled a lever that delivered a marshmallow to both himself and Monkey B. What happens when Monkey B sees his marshmallow as a mere byproduct of Monkey A’s self-interest? In this case, Monkey B reciprocates only 3% of the time. That’s even less than if Monkey A hadn’t given him a marshmallow at all.

“A true altruist versus an accidental altruist,” says Chen. “Monkeys are smart enough to distinguish.”

This distinction was surprising because it looks an awful lot like what humans do while making economic decisions. Chen wondered if monkeys resemble humans in their economic decision-making in other ways as well. He taught the monkeys to use metal washers as a form of money and then tested how well they conformed to one of the cardinal laws of economics: the law of demand. Economists often use a test called the Generalized Axiom of Revealed Preferences (GARP) to evaluate humans’ behavior. The test, in Chen’s words, puts parameters on behaviors considered “rational responses to price shocks.” Chen gave the test to the monkeys.

“When we test the capuchin monkeys on this basic rational response to price shocks, they pass GARP as well as any human beings that you can test,” Chen says. “In fact, it’s not until about age 10 or 11 that humans even start to pass GARP at this basic level that we observe the capuchin monkeys passing it at.”

Chen didn’t stop there. He found that monkeys even exhibit similarly irrational responses to humans with respect to, for example, the endowment effect.

“Every month, we would just be flabbergasted again at how sophisticated our monkeys looked,” Chen says. “Specifically, at economic activity. But also, the subtle ways in which they looked irrational and they looked emotional, in exactly the same ways that people do.“

So Chen had found that capuchin monkeys, once they were taught to use money, behaved rationally, like we do, when it comes to price theory; and irrationally, like we do, when it comes to the endowment effect. All of this research, however, had happened in tightly controlled lab experiments. What did animals’ economic activities look like in the wild?

Ronald Noë is a primatologist who spent two decades as a professor at the University of Strasbourg, in France. He got his start as a grad student under Frans de Waal, observing chimpanzees at the Arnhem Zoo in the Netherlands.

Noë was interested in studying cooperation in primates. By the early 1980s, he was observing baboons, in the wild, in Kenya. In these baboon groups, alpha males had access to females, and kept the lower-ranking males away. But Noë found that lower-ranking males could band together to challenge the alphas. If the low-ranking males were successful in chasing off the high-ranking male, they were entitled to a certain amount of access to the female.

But these bargains pose a dilemma. If two low-ranking males worked together to steal a female from an alpha, only one of them could mate with the female at a time. So how could this cooperation work?

At the time, there were, in biology circles, two primary theories of cooperation. One was “kin selection,” which involves helping out a closely related individual to make it more likely for your own genes to be passed on. But the baboons Noë was observing weren’t that closely related.

The other theory was called “reciprocal altruism” — you scratch my back, I’ll scratch yours. Kind of like the marshmallow monkeys that Chen had studied. According to this theory, the lower-ranking males should alternate who gets access to the female after they’ve chased away the alpha male. If the baboons didn’t alternate, then you would expect the baboon who didn’t have frequent access to the female to reject the compromise, to walk away.

Among the low-ranking baboons that Noë was studying, the most powerful one was named Stu. Noë noticed that Stu was getting more mating time than his less-powerful baboon partners. Despite that, the other baboons continued to form coalitions with Stu. Noë realized that reciprocal altruism could not explain the behavior he was seeing. It had to be something else.

Stu, it turned out, was utilizing his strength to get the best deals for himself. If a less-powerful baboon wasn’t willing to give Stu more mating time, Stu would simply move on to the next baboon. Stu could choose between partners, effectively bargaining to raise the price of his cooperation. Partner choice — that was Noë’s big idea. And with that insight, Noë realized that what he was observing was an economic transaction.

“Partner choice is what drives markets, what drives trade, what drives everything, because you force the others to outbid in competition,” he explains. “And that’s basically what a market is.”

When Noë published his research in the early 1990s, he called this situation a “biological market.” The idea didn’t go over so well with biologists, or the big biology journals.

Over time, however, Noë’s ideas started to gain traction. One of the biologists who picked up the idea, and extended it beyond primates, was a student of Noë’s, Redouan Bshary. Bshary studies animal behavior and teaches at the University of Neuchatel, in Switzerland. He started out doing fieldwork with Noë but ultimately transitioned to studying coral reefs.

One little fish captured Bshary’s attention. It’s called a cleaner wrasse, which is known for eating the parasites and dead scales off other fish.

Each cleaner wrasse sets up shop at a particular spot on the reef — kind of like a string of car washes — and the client fish line up at their favorite station to have their parasites removed. These fish have 2,000 cleaning interactions per day, and a single “client fish” typically visits a cleaner fish between 5 and 30 times a day.

Bshary began to observe patterns in the interactions of the cleaner fish with their clients. For one thing, there were two different types of client fish. There were the fish with limited range, who had access to just one cleaner wrasse. (Bshary called these fish “residents.”) Then there were the fish with more range, who could choose between many different cleaning stations. (These fish, Bshary called “visitors.”)

The cleaner fish, Bshary noticed, know the difference between visitors and residents — they vary their level of service depending on the fish they’re serving. For instance, they might make a resident fish wait while they service a visitor, knowing that a visitor might take his business elsewhere if there’s a line.

“And that’s exactly what visitors are doing,” Bshary says. “If the service is good, there’s a higher chance that you go back to the same station for your next inspection. If the service is lousy, you go to a different station for your next inspection.”

The cleaner fish even provide some special services, like massages, to certain fish.

This was exactly what Bshary had been looking for. The client fish were choosing their partners, and the cleaner fish were dialing their service up or down in response to the amount of choice that each client had. And, as economic theory would predict, the client fish with more choice reaped greater benefits.

Bshary has, by now, spent two decades studying the cleaner wrasse. Long enough to convince him — and his fellow animal behaviorists — that these animals plainly engage in what humans would recognize as economic transactions.

It’s not just baboons and cleaner fish. There’s growing evidence that biological markets exist across a very wide range of animals. Researchers have found that paper wasps, and even plants and fungi, engage in biological markets. A fungus-to-plant nutrient exchange is, of course, pretty far from what we humans think of as markets. There is no cognition going on there, or at least what we think of as cognition. Doesn’t trade require an intention to trade? And what about all the emotions that accompany intention?

Noë believes that is what makes biological markets more rational than human ones. The more we think, Noë suggests, the more capacity we have for cognitive activity or decision-making, and the more likely we are to be less rational.

“I think the less you use cognitive mechanisms, the least brain you have,” says Noë. “If you have no neurons, you have a better chance of being very rational in your behavior than when you use them. When you use your brain, you can make all kinds of mistakes.”

You can find the full Freakonomics Radio episode “The Invisible Paw,” at Freakonomics.com. You can also listen on Stitcher, Apple Podcasts, or any other podcast platform. Special thanks to Ben Crair, who contributed to this reporting and whose Bloomberg article “The Secret Economic Lives of Animals” first brought this topic to our attention.

written by

Stephen J. Dubner/ Freakonomics Radio

Stephen J. Dubner is co-author of the Freakonomics books and host of Freakonomics Radio.

title: The Invisible Paw
content_html:
What makes humans human? Is it our relentless curiosity? Our use of language? The collaborative and complex nature of our societies and communities?

Economists are likely to point to something else: our propensity for engaging in sophisticated systems of trade. “Nobody ever saw a dog make a fair and deliberate exchange of one bone for another with another dog,” the proto-economist Adam Smith once wrote. “Nobody ever saw one animal, by its gestures and natural cries, signify to another, this is mine, that, yours; I am willing to give this for that.”
